channel.title: SOC 4930 & SOC 5050

item.title: Quantiative Analysis - Applied Inferential Statistics
item.description: Currently Offered SOC 4930 & 5050 is Saint Louis University Sociology’s undergraduate and graduate introductory statistics course, which is currently being offered for Fall, 2017. This site is for sections taught by Assistant Professor Christopher Prener. Course Description This course provides an introduction to applied statistical analysis for both undergraduate and graduate students with an emphasis placed on statistical techniques that are most common in the sociological literature. The statistical techniques introduced include measures of central tendency and dispersion as well as measures of bivariate association.

item.title: Course Resources
item.description: In addition to the Syllabus and the Reading List, there are a number of other course resources you should be aware of. Course Website This course website will be updated regularly throughout the semester. I’ll add a page on the menu for each week, and include links to lecture slides, YouTube videos, and notes about specific topics. User’s Guide The User’s Guide is a companion document for the course that covers applications and processes not covered by one of the course textbooks.

item.title: Getting Started
item.description: Before you begin the semester, there are a number of things that I recommend that you do to help set yourself up for success. Before you do anything else, you should read through the Syllabus and the Reading List. Make sure you have a good sense of what is required for the course. If you have questions, bring them to the first day of class! Account Signups Get Started with Slack We’ll be using the messaging platform Slack as a space for “virtual office hours”.

item.title: Week 01 - Course Introduction
item.description: Lecture Slides Introducing R and RStudio At the very end of our first class, I introduced some basic aspects of R and RStudio. Since it was rushed, I’ve put together a quick video that summarizes what we went over and introduces some new functions as well. Please watch this before tackling the week two materials. I have also posted a quick reference sheet for relevant R functions for the week.

item.title: Week 02 - Working with Data (Part 1)
item.description: Lecture 02a - Introducing ggplot2 Slides Video Lecture Lecture 02b - Grammar of Graphics Slides Video Lecture Lecture 03 - Verbs for Cleaning Data Slides Video Lecture Lecture 04 - Structuring Notebooks Slides Video Lecture Data for Assignments The data that you need for many of the assignments this semester is available as an R package named testDriveR.

item.title: Week 03 - Describing Distributions
item.description: Lecture Slides Using GitHub to Store Working Files for the Course If you want to GitHub to store your working files (as opposed to the finish submission versions you submit via your Assignments repository), you can sign-up for a discounted student plan here. Choose “Student” and “Individual Account”, and answer any additional prompts they have. Be prepared to attach a photo of your student ID. If you do this, you want to be sure to include a .

item.title: Week 04 - Probability and Bayes' Theorem
item.description: Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions I’ve posted the first weekly prep of the semester. The instructions are available in the Week-04 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication Probability in the News FiveThirtyEight just published a great article on the use probability in news media coverage. The article raises important points about how error in public polling is communicated:

item.title: Week 05 - The Distribution of Random Variables
item.description: Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-05 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication Grappling with p-values Here are a couple of links for digging further into what p-values are and how we explain them: American Statistical Association’s Statement on p-values ``Mission Improbable: A Concise and Precise Definition of P-Value” - Science Magazine interview with Victor De Gruttola ``Science Isn’t Broken” - FiveThirtyEight article on p-values ``Not Even Scientists Can Easily Explain P-values” - FiveThirtyEight article on p-values, includes the video I mentioned in class Andrew Gelman’s views on p-values ``Abandon Statistical Significance” - Andrew Gelman and others Gelman and John Carlin suggest some solutions for the ``p-value communication problem” ``It will be much harder to call new findings ‘significant’ if this team gets its way” - Science Magazine article on changing culture around p-values Histograms with the Normal Distribution Overlaid in ggplot2 I introduced the idea of a histogram with a normal distribution overlaid during this week’s lecture, but purposely did not include the syntax on our quick reference sheet for R functions.

item.title: Week 06 - Foundations for Inference
item.description: Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-06 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication

item.title: Week 07 - Difference of Means (Part 1)
item.description: Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-07 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication YAML Headers for RMarkdown Documents The area at the top of your RMarkdown documents is known as a YAML header (Wikipedia site and YAML project homepage). YAML stands for “YAML Ain’t Markup Language” (a bit of nerdy humor!

item.title: Week 08 - Difference of Means (Part 2)
item.description: Lecture Slides Weekly Prep Instructions The instructions for this week’s weekly prep are available in the Week-08 GitHub repository. Make sure you submit your work and answers by the beginning of class on Monday! Replication New and Updated Packages for Class We are going to be using a bunch of new packages this week! Here is a list of packages to install using install.packages(): car effsize gapminder ggridges pwr stargazer You will also need to install a new package, stlData, from GitHub and update the testDriveR package:
